rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 10–28
rsbNotes.text:
10:1–28:27 The Divided Kingdom. In this section the writer makes use of 1 Kin. 12–2 Kin. 17. His record of the period of the divided monarchy does not rehearse the harsh condemnation of the northern tribes found in Kings, focusing instead on events in Judah where the temple was and the Davidic king lived. Throughout this section, the writer reports how the conditions in the kingdom depended on the nation’s faithfulness to God. As readers considered these events, they could see clearly the choices for blessing and curse in their own day.

In telling about Rehoboam’s kingship, the writer makes broad use of Kings (cf. 10:1–11:4 with 1 Kin. 12:1–24; 12:9–16 with 1 Kin. 14:21, 25–31), while presenting the material in accord with his own theological understanding and emphasis. The account is presented in two parts (chs. 10; 11 and 12:1–14), each part narrating a problematic situation, prophetic encounter, and divine blessing. The conclusion is a notice of his wars with Jeroboam and his death (12:15, 16). The chapters impress on the readers God’s curse against pride and infidelity and the benefits of living in humility and obedience to the prophetic word (20:20 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 17:1–21:3
rsbNotes.text: 17:1–21:3 The account of Jehoshaphat’s reign incorporates most of the record in Kings (cf. 1 Kin. 22:1–35 with 2 Chr. 18:2–34; 1 Kin. 22:41–46, 49 with 2 Chr. 20:31–36), adding some material and a summary of his reign.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 21:2–20
rsbNotes.text: 21:2–20 The historian supplements the record of Jehoram’s reign in Kings (2 Kin. 8:16–24); in Kings the assessment is negative. Jehoram reigned as co-regent with Jehoshaphat 853–848 b.c. (2 Kin. 1:17; 3:1), and by himself 848–841 b.c. He murdered his brothers (21:2–7); Edom and Libnah rebelled against him (21:8–10); he fell into idolatry (21:11); and Elijah prophesied an impending judgment (21:12–20).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 21:2
rsbNotes.text: 21:2 brothers. The murder of Jehoram’s brothers recorded here is additional to the account in Kings (2 Kin. 8:16–22). On the other side, Kings describes how Solomon disposed of Adonijah, an event omitted from Chronicles (1 Kin. 2:24).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 21:4
rsbNotes.text: 21:4 Israel. See note 10:1.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 21:5
rsbNotes.text: 21:5 eight years. As sole monarch (21:2–20 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 21:7
rsbNotes.text: 21:7 not willing to destroy the house of David. The house of David was on the brink of annihilation. Jehoram deserved to die, but God preserved his life to fulfill His promise of a permanent dynasty to David. Despite the sins of individual descendants of David, the Davidic line would never be entirely rejected (1 Chr. 17:7–14 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 21:8–10
rsbNotes.text: 21:8–10 God’s displeasure toward Jehoram became evident when these two nations subject to Judah successfully rebelled against him.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 21:8
rsbNotes.text: 21:8 Edom. Jehoshaphat had subjugated Edom through righteous dependence on God (20:1–30). Jehoram, however, failed in his attempt.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 21:10
rsbNotes.text:
21:10 to this day. See note 1 Chr. 4:41.

Libnah. An area between Judah and Philistia.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 21:11–20
rsbNotes.text: 21:11–20 This episode illustrating the depths of Jehoram’s sin is additional to the account in Kings.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 21:11
rsbNotes.text:
21:11 made high places. While Asa and Jehoshaphat failed to rid the land of all high places (14:3 note), Jehoram actively built them (cf. 28:25).

whoredom. Perhaps literally through involvement with prostitution in pagan worship rituals, or metaphorically through spiritual infidelity (1 Chr. 5:25).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 21:12
rsbNotes.text: 21:12 Elijah. The only mention of the prophet in Chronicles; compare the lengthy account of his prophetic activities in 1 Kin. 17–2 Kin. 2.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 21:14–19
rsbNotes.text: 21:14–19 The judgment against Jehoram was twofold. God promises “a great plague” on the people and on Jehoram’s family, a threat fulfilled by the attacks of Philistines and Arabs. Second, Jehoram becomes terminally ill, as promised. The emphasis is on immediate retribution (1 Chr. 28:9 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 21:19
rsbNotes.text: 21:19 made no fire. Contrast with the response to Asa’s death (16:14). Jehoram (21:20), Joash (24:25), Ahaz (28:27), and Manasseh (33:20) died in ignominy. Amon was disgracefully assassinated (cf. 33:24).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 21:20
rsbNotes.text:
21:20 Chronicles supplements the record given in 2 Kin. 8:24 of Jehoram’s death and burial with details that reveal his utter disgrace.

eight years. See note on v. 5.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 22:1–9
rsbNotes.text: 22:1–9 The record of Chronicles ties Ahaziah (841 b.c.) closely to his father Jehoram (21:4–20). Both kings were deeply influenced by Athaliah and so are evaluated negatively (21:6; 22:3, 4). In both reigns, the Davidic dynasty barely escaped annihilation (21:16, 17; 22:7–9).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 22:3–9
rsbNotes.text: 22:3–9 Chronicles presents Ahaziah’s rapid downfall as divine chastisement for his alliance with the northern kingdom (16:2 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 22:5
rsbNotes.text: 22:5 Hazael. See 1 Kin. 19:15 and 2 Kin. 8:7–15.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 22:8
rsbNotes.text: 22:8 Jehu was executing judgment. Kings reports that Elisha anointed Jehu to destroy the house of Omri (2 Kin. 9:1–10:31). The death of Ahaziah was part of this judgment.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 22:9
rsbNotes.text: 22:9 They buried him. Ahaziah received an honorable burial, not because of his own character, but because of his grandfather Jehoshaphat.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 22:10–24:27
rsbNotes.text: 22:10–24:27 Compare 2 Kin. chs. 11 and 12 on the record of Joash. This portion of Chronicles illustrates the close association between king and priest. The Davidic line was preserved by Jehoshabeath and her husband, the priest Jehoiada (22:10–23:21); the Davidic king served faithfully under the influence of Jehoiada (24:1–16); the king failed when he rejected the instruction of Jehoiada’s son, and put him to death (24:17–27). Cooperation of king and priest was essential. See also Zech. 3; 4; 6:9–15.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 22:10–12
rsbNotes.text: 22:10–12 Jehoshaphat’s marriage alliance (18:1 note) finally yielded its worst result. Athaliah nearly destroyed the Davidic line in her quest to establish herself as queen.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 22:11
rsbNotes.text: 22:11 Joash. Reigned 835–796 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 22:12
rsbNotes.text: 22:12 Athaliah. Athaliah was the only queen to rule in Judah (841–835 b.c.).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 23:1–11
rsbNotes.text: 23:1–11 The Zadokite priest Jehoiada resisted Queen Athaliah and gained the military support necessary for temple and political reform.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 23:2
rsbNotes.text: 23:2 through Judah . . . all the cities. This verse expands the account in Kings depicting Joash’s widespread support in Judah (1 Chr. 11:1 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 23:3
rsbNotes.text: 23:3 as the Lord spoke. See note 1 Chr. 17:14.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 23:11
rsbNotes.text: 23:11 the testimony. Probably the covenant made in 23:3; compare also Deut. 17:18–20.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 23:13
rsbNotes.text: 23:13 trumpeters . . . singers . . . musical instruments. See 1 Chr. 15:16 note.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 23:16
rsbNotes.text: 23:16 made a covenant. See note 15:12.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 23:17
rsbNotes.text: 23:17 house of Baal. Probably a shrine to Baal erected for Athaliah (cf. 1 Kin. 11:1–8).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 23:18–19
rsbNotes.text: 23:18, 19 This account emphasizes more than 2 Kin. 11:18 that the new temple order under Jehoiada and Joash was according to Mosaic and Davidic design. The books of Chronicles were written in the time of reconstruction following the return of the Jews from exile in Babylonia, and such encouragement was appropriate.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 23:21
rsbNotes.text: 23:21 quiet. See note 1 Chr. 22:9.
